title: 108_hr851
content:
The Trade Accountability Study Act may be cited as the Trade Impact Commission. The Trade Impact Review Commission is established to determine the impact of exports and imports between the United States and NAFTA countries since January 1, 1994, including job creation and loss. The Trade Impact Review Commission is tasked with assessing the changes in exports and imports between the United States and China since December 11, 2001. This includes evaluating job creation and loss resulting from these trade activities. The findings will be submitted to relevant committees and government officials. The Trade Impact Review Commission, composed of 5 members appointed by various officials, will assess changes in US-China trade since December 11, 2001, focusing on job creation and loss. Findings and recommendations for strengthening the US labor force will be submitted to relevant committees and government officials. The Trade Impact Review Commission will consist of members with knowledge or expertise in relevant matters, representing diverse economic and professional backgrounds from different regions of the United States. Members may come from various sectors including academia, government, nonprofit organizations, or industry. The Trade Impact Review Commission members will be appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate leaders to ensure fair representation of different viewpoints on studied matters. The Trade Impact Review Commission members will be appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate leaders. The majority and minority leaders of the Senate will conduct consultations and make appointments within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Each Commission member serves for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled promptly, and a Chair and Vice Chair are selected from among its members. Meetings must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Trade Impact Review Commission members are appointed by various officials. The Commission holds its first meeting once all members are appointed, followed by subsequent meetings called by the Chair. A majority of members constitute a quorum, and members are compensated for their duties. The Trade Impact Review Commission members are prohibited from receiving additional compensation as federal employees or Members of Congress. They are entitled to travel expenses and may procure temporary services and detail personnel from federal agencies to assist in their duties. The Trade Impact Review Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Members or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies. The Trade Impact Review Commission can use the United States mails and receive administrative support services. They must submit a report with findings and recommendations within 180 days of their first meeting and terminate 30 days after submitting the report. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of Appropriations: Sums may be appropriated as necessary for this section. SEC. 3. FUTURE NEGOTIATIONS: The President must consider Trade Impact Commission findings in trade agreement negotiations.

SEC. 4. PRESIDENTIAL CERTIFICATIONS: The President must report annually on NAFTA countries' compliance with environmental and labor commitments, and China's obligations on environment and worker rights.

SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The terms defined in this Act include NAFTA, NAFTA country, North American Agreement on Environmental Cooperation, and North American Agreement on Labor Cooperation. The curr_chunk refers to the definition of a term in the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act.
